705688f-b.title: Brooklyn: Meeker Avenue - Gardner Avenue
705688f-b.text:
Meeker Ave., south side, between Gardkner Ave., and Newtown Creek,
alleged to have been built by Humphrey Clay in 1667, it stood until
1921 when it was demolished about 50 or 60 ft. from Newtown Creek.
The owners of this property are as follews:- patented in 1646 by Adan
Mott who sold to William Geulding; who sold to Clandine Barbine and
Anthony Jerve of Newgate Kills; who sold to Jacob Steendam in 1653.
It was again patented by Humphrey Clay in 1667. He operated a ferry
here as late as 1670. His son Clay sold to Alexander Baird of Hemp-
stead, who left it to his wife Magdaleun. The first recorded sale is
in 1749, from Josiah Paterson to Joost Dorre, who by will in 1793 left
his real estate of Boshwick and Newtown to his sons, George and Peter.
The former conveyed to Peter in 1795, the lattere will convey in 1828
part to Anthony Hulst and the rest including the house to John Reis.
From 1880 to 1924 William Blesser, and his heirs were owners.
1920.
Eugene L. Armbruster Cellection.
MAr BE REPRODUCED.
705688f-b.folder: Meeker Avenue & Gardner Avenue, Brooklyn, NY

The former conveyed to Peter in 1795, the lattere will convey in 1828
part to Anthony Hulst and the rest including the house to John Reis.
From 1880 to 1924 William Blesser, and his heirs were owners.
1920.

705686f-a.title: Brooklyn: Meeker Avenue - Gardner Avenue
705686f-a.text:
416-420 Meeker Ave., near the S.E. corner of Gardner Ave.
October 29, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

705690f-b.title: Brooklyn: Meeker Avenue - Gardner Avenue
705690f-b.text:
Meeker Ave., south aide, between Gardiner Ave., and Newtown Creek,
shewing Williaw Bleser's house at right, and the site ef the Durie
home in its rear.
1922.
